findings.title: Predictable randomness using block.timestamp
findings.explanation: Using block.timestamp to seed randomness is predictable and can be manipulated by miners, allowing them to influence the lottery outcome.
findings.fix_suggestion: Use a secure randomness source such as a commit–reveal scheme or an oracle like Chainlink VRF instead of block data.

findings.title: State update after external call
findings.explanation: The contract transfers funds to the bank and player before resetting the pot, which could allow a reentrant call to manipulate pot if  more gas were forwarded.
findings.fix_suggestion: Set pot to zero before making any external calls, following the Checks-Effects-Interactions pattern to prevent reentrancy.

findings.title: Integer overflow in pot accumulation
findings.explanation: The pot is incremented by msg.value without any overflow check, which could wrap around after enough additions.
findings.fix_suggestion: Use a SafeMath library for all arithmetic operations to guard against overflows and underflows.

findings.title: Denial of Service on bank.transfer
findings.explanation: If the bank address is a contract whose fallback function reverts or requires more than 2300 gas, bank.transfer will fail and revert the entire play() call, blocking winners from being paid.
findings.fix_suggestion: Adopt a withdrawal pattern for the fee or handle transfer failures gracefully (e.g., using send and letting the bank withdraw later).
